content.question:
Half-Reaction
 Standard Reduction Potential, <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus one electron produce A g solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Ag(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="positive 0.80 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="M g with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus 2 electrons produce M g solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Mg(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 2.37 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.37</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

The galvanic cell shown above generates a cell potential of <math alttext="positive 3.17 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3.17</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when operated under standard conditions. A second galvanic cell is made from the same two metals, and the measured cell potential is <math alttext="positive 3.25 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3.25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following could be the reason for the second cell having a greater cell potential?

choices.label: The mass of the <math alttext="A g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode in the second cell is greater than in first, resulting in a reduction potential greater than <math alttext="0.80 volt" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.80</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The mass of the <math alttext="M g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode in the second cell is smaller than in the first, resulting in a reduction potential lower than <math alttext="negative 2.37 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.37</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="the molar concentration of M g with a positive 2 charge is greater than 1 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the molar concentration of A g with a positive 1 charge equals 1 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the second cell, resulting in <math alttext="Q is greater than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Q is equal to 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for the first cell.

<math alttext="the molar concentration of A g with a positive 1 charge is greater than 1 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the molar concentration of M g with a positive 2 charge equals 1 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the second cell, resulting in <math alttext="Q is less than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Q is equal to 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for the first cell.

content.answer: <math alttext="the molar concentration of A g with a positive 1 charge is greater than 1 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the molar concentration of M g with a positive 2 charge equals 1 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the second cell, resulting in <math alttext="Q is less than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Q is equal to 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for the first cell.

skill.text: 6.D: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using chemical principles or laws, or using mathematical justification.
